title: Johnny Depp told to hand over drug and booze medical records in case against Amber Heard
text:

Hollywood star Johnny Depp has been ordered by a judge to provide drug and alcohol medical records during his ongoing defamation case with ex-wife Amber Heard.

The $50 million case started in 2016 when Depp, 56, claimed Heard, 33, defamed him when she penned an op-ed on domestic abuse.

The pair wed in 2016, and finalised their divorce in 2017.

Though the actor wasn't named in the piece, he decided to pursue legal action by suing her for $50million.

This past Friday, Heard's attorneys told the Virginia court that they had requested documents about Depp that might shed light on whether he had abused different partners in the past.

These partners were not named, but now Depp has been granted an amount of time to produce the documents relating to his alcohol and drug use.

(Image: X03298)

These records were deemed relevant as Heard's lawyers say it's what fuelled the alleged abuse.

Deadline reported that Heard's lawyer J Benjamin Rottenborn last month said: "Mr Depp cannot seek to litigate the truth of Ms Heard's allegations about his violent and abusive behaviour while intoxicated, insist on proceeding without a protective order, and then blithely refuse to produce evidence that confirms the truth of those allegations on grounds of relevance and 'privacy.'"

They also reported that the judge agreed, and ordered on October 18th: "By November 15th 2019, Plaintiff must produce all non-privileged, responsive documents requested by Defendant's document requests."

Heard is trying to prove that Depp did abuse her when they were married - something he denies.

This led her lawyers to ask the judge to let them provide proof he might have acted similarly toward other partners.

(Image: PA)

(Image: Clint Brewer / Splash News)

On the other partners Depp allegedly may have abused, Rottenborn said: "He says he is not a perpetrator of domestic violence. So we have requested documents relating to Mr Depp's commission of domestic violence against other romantic partners."

Depp's team slammed this request as irrelevant, before the judge asked why Depp, in his lawsuit, said that he had never committed domestic violence toward anyone.

Depp's lawyer replied: "Mr Depp understood that this case, since the public op-ed, is going to be in the public press. And so it's important for him to say that."

Heard's lawyers attempted to keep the case private, and she said she didn't want her life, or the lives of those close to her, in the public eye.

Depp's attorneys, meanwhile, have made repeated claims that he has "nothing to hide."

The lawyer representing the star slammed the latest claims to DailyMail.com , saying that they were all part of a "notorious abuse hoax."

(Image: Getty)

They continued: "Having been sued for defamation for her notorious abuse hoax, Amber Heard's #TimesUp lawyer doesn't waste any time trying to prove the unprovable, or dispute the mountain of evidence showing her fraud.

"Instead, they do what the guilty always do, compounding the original crime with new false allegations and other smearing innuendo.

"There is a public trial February 3rd, and that is when the truth replaces PR."

(Image: Alcon Entertainment)

Other pieces to evidence to be presented to the court will be Herad's texts with Tesla CEO Elon Musk, who she had a romance with after splitting from Depp.

Roberta Kaplan, who represents Heard, said to DailyMail.com : "It is Mr Depp who started this lawsuit on the theory that Ms Heard somehow made up all the abuse that forced her to obtain a restraining order against Mr Depp back in 2016.

"Now that the facts in his own lawsuit are making him uncomfortable, Mr Depp wants to hide evidence commonly understood to be connected to incidents of domestic violence: his decades-long abuse of drugs and alcohol, his past history of violence and medical records showing among other things the laundry list of prescription medications he takes daily and injuries from his drug-induced rages.

"Mr Depp started this fight. Ms Heard intends to finish it by proving, if necessary, the truth of what really happened."
description: Depp is suing his ex-wife Amber Heard over an op-ed she wrote in which she discussed domestic abuse, despite not naming him explicitly
